target_title: "Failed to scan, Error communicating with scanner" for Canon Lide400
"Failed to scan, Error communicating with scanner" for Canon Lide400

note.body:

I can confirm this behaviour (v46 on Ubuntu 24.04 LTS). 

I also notice that shift + scroll wheel doesn't scroll horizontally, as I would have expected. Not sure if that is related...

In any case, closing.

Thank You for Your reply.
Unfortunately after i tried again by installing software and drivers from scratch i had no luck and above that the scanner was interfering with the boot process. So i had to uninstall it completely and just wait for a new driver version from EPSON, if and when..., as i believe that this is what the problem is. It proved to not be compatible with this new version 22 as it was working fine up until version 2.3
Best Regards

Set resource_base_path for icon lookup

note.body:
@gang65 Any chance you could take a look at this? It's a one-line change to fix the issue (#422) that simple-scan is currently missing ALL of its custom icons, due to an unset resource base path.

The snap build is failing because,

> Issues while validating snapcraft.yaml: The 'apps/simple-scan/extensions[0]' property does not match the required schema: 'gnome' is not one of ['flutter-stable', 'flutter-beta', 'flutter-dev', 'flutter-master', 'gnome-3-28', 'gnome-3-34', 'gnome-3-38', 'kde-neon', 'ros1-noetic', 'ros2-foxy']

...which has nothing to do with this MR.

target_title: No format switching when saving

note.body:
Tested in Document Scanner 46.0 on Fedora (package `simple-scan-46.0-2.fc41.x86_64`).

## Steps to reproduce:
1. Scan anything.
2. Click the save button in the header bar.
3. In the save dialog, change the file format selection from (by default) PDF to JPEG (or anything else).
4. Click save.

## Expected results:
The file should be saved as a JPEG or whatever format you selected in step 3.

## Actual results:
The file is saved as a PDF.

## Expected behaviour:
Changing the file format selection should adjust the file name field by changing or adding an extension to match.  When you click Save, the file should be saved in the selected format, regardless of the file name entered, with the filename entered, exactly as shown before clicking Save.  This is the behaviour in the GIMP (which also defaults the format selection to "By Extension" and warns before saving with a "mismatched" extension).

Alternatively, the dialog should be laid out so it doesn't look as if you're choosing a file format for the output file with that combo box.  (See screenshot below.)

## Actual behaviour:
The file format selection has no effect on the format used to save the file.

If the file name has an extension corresponding to one of the supported formats, the file is saved in that format.  (e.g. if you enter "test.jpg", the file will be saved as JPEG.)

If the file name contains a period but does not end with one of the supported extensions, the file is saved as a JPEG with the exact entered name.  (e.g. if you enter "section 1.2", the file will be saved as JPEG named "section 1.2")

If the file name does not contain a period, the file is saved as a PDF with the entered name and a ".pdf" extension.  (e.g. if you enter "section 1", the file will be saved as a PDF named "section 1.pdf")

## See also:
#313 is substantially the same issue.

## Screenshot:
This is immediately after step 3 in my steps above.  Despite having selected "JPEG (compressed)", the file will be saved as a PDF.

![Screenshot_From_2024-11-15_21-54-16](/uploads/579036a1987d97bfafd53f7150a1fc6c/Screenshot_From_2024-11-15_21-54-16.png)

Note how the bottom of the dialog is [file format selection] [file name entry] [save button] all in a line together, and these seem like the required parts of the dialog.  The file format selection is actually not required and has no effect on the saved file, but it looks as if it would because of its position in line with the file name and save button, which do and are used sequentially.

note.body: I'm using v46.0 from Flathub on Fedora 41. Initially the horizontal scrollbar shows up, but when I rotate one of the pages it visibly disappears. The scrollbar must still there because I can click where it should be and the view scrolls, but its completely invisible. Starting a new document/scan makes it visible again.

target_title: Icons in Simple Scan Reorder Pages are blurred

note.body:
I took a look at this just now. Some observations:

1. I'm seeing the same thing, off an install from distro packaging in Fedora 40.
2. It's not just that dialog. All of the application's custom icons are missing. (The icon that's supposed to be in the "Scan" button in the main window, for example.) The only one not missing is the application icon, for reasons that will become clear momentarily.
3. The custom icons _are_ present in the application resources (confirmed with `gresource list /usr/bin/simple-scan`)
4. Using the Gtk inspector on the application shows that all of the widgets with placeholder icons have their `icon-name` property set (e.g. `scan-type-adf-symbolic` for the Scan button, with my scanner), but their `gicon` property is `(nil)`.
5. The application icon at the center of the main window, OTOH, is loading because it's _also_ installed as `/usr/share/icons/hicolor/scalable/apps/org.gnome.SimpleScan.svg` on the filesystem.

So, it's clear that even though the custom icons are _available_, they're not being loaded from the resources. But the UI definitions still _are_, so it's not a general resource access issue. Just an icon resource access issue.

If I run the application with `GTK_DEBUG=icontheme,builder,iconfallback` in the environment, when it initially starts up I see a lot of messages about icon cache and resource directory scanning... but none about the `/org/gnome/SimpleScan/icons/scalable/actions/` path the icon resources actually live in:

```console
$ GTK_DEBUG=icontheme,builder,iconfallback simple-scan
look for icon cache in /usr/share/icons/Adwaita
found icon cache for /usr/share/icons/Adwaita
look for icon cache in /usr/share/icons/AdwaitaLegacy
found icon cache for /usr/share/icons/AdwaitaLegacy
look for icon cache in /usr/share/icons/hicolor
found icon cache for /usr/share/icons/hicolor
scanning resource directory /org/gtk/libgtk/icons/16x16/actions/
scanning resource directory /org/gnome/Adwaita/icons/16x16/actions/
scanning resource directory /org/gtk/libgtk/icons/16x16/animations/
scanning resource directory /org/gnome/Adwaita/icons/16x16/animations/
look for icon cache in /var/lib/flatpak/exports/share/icons/hicolor
```

But if I run e.g. `file-roller` the same way, note the differences:

```console
$ GTK_DEBUG=icontheme,builder,iconfallback file-roller
look for icon cache in /usr/share/icons/Adwaita

scanning resource directory /org/gnome/FileRoller/icons/16x16/stock/data/
```

Same thing for `nautilus` (take my word for it), but with `/org/gnome/nautilus/icons/...` instead.

Searching the `nautilus` and `file-roller` source, I found one commonality that isn't present in the `simple-scan` source: `g_application_set_resource_base_path()`.

```console
$ cd /path/to/nautilus/src
$ grep -i resource_base **/*(.)
nautilus-application.c:    g_application_set_resource_base_path (G_APPLICATION (self), "/org/gnome/nautilus");

$ cd /path/to/file-roller/
$ grep -i resource_base src/**/*(.)                         
src/fr-application.c:	g_application_set_resource_base_path (application, "/org/gnome/FileRoller");

$ cd /path/to/simple-scan/
$ grep -i resource_base src/**/*(.)
$
```

Conclusion: **Either** Simple Scan needs to call `g_application_set_resource_base_path()` (or the vala equivalent) to set the resource base path to `/org/gnome/SimpleScan`, **OR** it needs to store the icons in its resources under the path `/org/gnome/Adwaita/icons/scalable/actions`, because that appears to be the default base path it's currently building with.

target_title: Icons in Simple Scan Reorder Pages are blurred

note.body:
I'm seeing this as well - currently on version 46.0, as provided out of the box with Fedora 41.

Reproduced this originally with an upgrade from Fedora 39 -> 40, then continued to see this on multiple clean installs of Fedora 40, and the issue survived the upgrade from 40 -> 41.

Is there anything I could try or check to help narrow this issue down?

Which exact GTK version is used?

GTK 4.16 uses Vulkan as default renderer. You could try setting `GSK_RENDERER=ngl`.
